creditline: Gift of Mrs. John L. Bates in memory of her father, Russell T. Mount, Class of 1902
markings: Watermark: interlaced double C, cross of Lorraine between, crown above
inscribed: lower margin of plate: IVDOCVS CITERMANS/ANTVERPIENSIS PICTOR MAGNI DVCIS...; l.l. of plate: Ant. van Dyck fecit aqua forti; G.H.

makers.displaydate: 1599–1641; born Antwerp, Belgium; died London, England
makers.displaymaker: Anthony van Dyck, 1599–1641; born Antwerp, Belgium; died London, England

texts.textentryhtml: Like many painters, Van Dyck appreciated the flexibility of the etching process, in which an artist draws freely with a needle onto a copper plate coated with an acid-resistant wax. As is characteristic of Van Dyck’s etched plates, there is an arresting raw aesthetic to the adjoining impression of the first state. This later state reveals changes made after the publisher Gillis Hendricx acquired the Iconography plates in 1644: the technical imperfections were burnished away from the copper plate, some lines were darkened, and lettering was added beneath the image. Despite the more polished look that resulted, no attempt was made to complete details left unfinished by the artist, thereby preserving his original sketch.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1976," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 36, no. 1 (1977): p. 28-40.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1976," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 36, no. 1 (1977): p. 28-40., p. 37
